abstractText: Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT) tags have been utilized as a research and management tool in the Columbia River Basin since 1987. PIT-tagging juvenile salmonids collected at juvenile fish screening and bypass facility can be used to conduct site-specific evaluations, estimate survival and travel time in reaches above and below the facility, or for determining the proportion of fish using the facility. A major advantage of PIT-tags over many other marking or tagging methods is that PIT-tagged fish do not need to be physically recaptured; they only need to pass by an automated tag interrogation system. Other advantages include its small size, individual fish identification, long life expectancy (no battery), and relatively simple tagging procedure.
title: PIT-tagging Juvenile Salmonids Collected at a Juvenile Fish Screening and Bypass Facility v1.0
